title: an important read

title: Verified Purchase
content: I think the author, Christy Lefteri, missed an amazing opportunity to educate the world about this crisis in Syria.  I wanted to love this book.  I knew it would be a difficult and sad subject matter and I was ready for it.  Unfortunately, I was terribly disappointed in this book.  When I find myself not picking up the current book I’m reading, I know I’m not loving it.  At about 50% I went and checked the two- and three-star reviews on Amazon.  I was correct, I wasn’t the only one.  I love historical fiction and especially loved Mark Sullivan’s Beneath A Scarlet Sky and The Last Green Valley.  He took the bits and pieces FROM THE DISTANT PAST and wove both stories in to amazing novels.  The crisis in Syria is a very recent, current event. Based on the author’s front-line experience helping Syrian refugees, I expected a much better story.  The author teaches creative writing.  Maybe she was trying to appeal to a difference audience or maybe tried to be TOO creative.  Instead, just tell the story!  The book had a good foundation but got lost.

title: Heart-wrenching and Eye-opening
content: As we sit in relative safety and watch and listen to news reports on the number of "illegal" migrants entering our country or Europe, we are usually not exposed to the true humanity of the crises. Instead, the migrant situation is a flashpoint political topic. This book instead offers a glimpse into what individuals must go through to leave dangerous conditions and try to find a peaceful existence somewhere in the world, where they and their families are safe, like us. For me, this story was eye-opening.  It helped me comprehend the absolute desperation of these people and how much they've lost and sacrificed. I hope we can demonstrate compassion while developing some solutions for these people without sacrificing the safety we have and that most of them seek. Thank you, Ms. Lefteri.

title: What a great book!
content: Wanted to learn about Syria and the refugee issue.  That I did. This book is full of flashbacks and mental states that makes it difficult for the reader to know where the characters are and when, what is real and what is not, and most frustrating of all whether they were actually granted final asylum in Great Britain so the main character could return to beekeeping and whether the wife's eyesight returned so she could continue her art. title: The Human Tragedy of Shifting Geopolitical Sands
content: Wow..we who live in the west have no idea how bad it is in Syria. I don’t have the words. Its too tragic to speak about what these people have experienced. Im glad I read about it. A piece of ours hearts should be exposed to what others have endured. You feel something inside you that makes you not want to speak about it. But you can read about it. And you will get a glipse of the horrific circumstances these people have been forced fo experience. You feel like you are there with them watching, but they can’t see you. And because of that, you would never ask an actual Cyrian person what it was like to experience  and eyewitness the barbarity and madness that were heaped upon them. It just feels rude to even speak of it after reading this story. But you can’t help but connect with their suffering and loss. But its important to know about it and get a glimpse of what others endured. It somehow felt like a movie instead of a novel. It was as if we were there watching their loss, trauma, and bewilderment those must’ve experienced. I can see the chatacters as if I was watching a movie. The characters were so real, you felt like you knew them and their thoughts and emotions. THIS GIVES YOU AN IDEA WHAT MODERN WAR REALLY LOOKS LIKE.

title: A Fantastic Read!
content: I am a huge fan of Khaled Hosseini.  I absolutely loved The Kite Runner, A Thousand Splendid Suns and And The Mountains Echoed.  Because of my love for those books, I had very high expectations for Christy Lefteri's The Beekeeper of Aleppo.  I am pleased to say that The Beekeeper of Aleppo does not disappoint.  Ms. Lefteri has masterfully crafted a heartbreaking story of the plight of a Syrian refugee family without relying on graphic violence or predictable heartbreaking cliches.  Nuri is a beekeeper and native son of Aleppo; his wife Afra is an artist.  As the civil war escalates in Aleppo, Nuri loses his beloved bees, Afra her sight and both of them their only son.  With nothing left to keep them in Syria, they are have no choice but to follow Nuri's cousin to England in the hope of rebuilding their lives.  Ms. Lefteri has succeeded in guiding the reader on a journey from Syria, into Turkey, across the sea to the filth and despair of a Greek refugee camp and then finally to the U.K.  It is in Greece that Nuri and Afra demonstrate the resilience of the human spirit and the lengths the desperate are willing to take to survive, and the depravity of those willing to prey on them  I cannot recommend this book highly enough!

title: Deeply disturbing and equally disappointing book.....it just didn’t  work
content: This book grabs your attention and focuses you on it’s two main characters. The story starts out in a compelling way but the last part of the book is confusing, almost incoherent and way too annoying to finish.  While you are reading it you will see constant contradictions about where the characters are and what they are doing. Long stretches make no sense because you can’t tell if what you are reading is real or just a dream. The author says this book is about a central question: “how do we see?“ I suppose the author is referring to one of the characters having dramatic blindness. But the book has almost nothing to do with “how we see“ the author lost her way, did not know how to make the story move forward, and left the book without an incoherent ending. I do not understand how the editors with this unfinished manuscript be published in this form. As I said the author can write compelling fiction but she can’t tie things together in a way that makes sense. You will certainly suffer along with the characters, but you will not know what is real and what is not. This book needs another three or four edits and the author needs to rethink her lack of clarity. If you read this Book to answer the question “how do we see?” Then you will get no answer. The author did not have one and the book does not supply one.

title: Verified Purchase
content: I almost never write book reviews but this is a special book. This is a book with stories on many different levels. There is the outward story of the journey of a couple to flee the Syrian war. And there is the inward journey of a couple traumatized by war losses which has left them strangers to each other. It is a book about immigrants, forced to flee for their lives leaving everything they have known and loved.  It is a book about the best and the worst in the human spirit. It is a book about the extremes the human psyche will go to to deal with trauma that is overwhelming. And as is true for all trauma survivors, this wise author knows that the journey towards healing is through love and connection.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2023

title: Sadness. Life is fragile
content: I read every word and never got bored.  Only my personal life took me away from it for about 10 days and then I was right back in with all my senses.  This is an amazing story that rarely falters and grips the reader with the simplicity and complexity of realism.  What's it like to be a refugee from our most egregious wars?  You'll get a taste of it and more from this classic novel.  Don't miss it!

title: Verified Purchase
content: We have been hearing of the horrors year after year faced by the innocent victims of the war and Assad's regime.This accurate portrayal of a  couple who have lost everything and were forced to flee Allepo to make their way to asylum and a new life brings the reality of an unimaginable period of time to life in a,way that the news can't. If it moves you to in some way to help these and other political refugees through donations to international aid groups, I am sure the author's purpose in writing this novel will have been met.

title: Heart rendering
content: The story is tough to digest, though it’s emotion is well-communicated and it makes a lot more sense at the very end. To those who think words are missing, the sentence is supposed to complete with the title of the second part of the chapter. It’s the narrator unable to stay in the present without being drawn to the past that he’s living through at the same time.

title: Verified Purchase
content: Enough of the camps and the temporary housing. It's like beating a dead horse over and over. I actually put it down after around 150 pages-it just got tedious. Ms. Lefteri's writing is very good and she can spin a page turning story, and I appreciate what she did for the immigrant population and I appreciate also her experiences, but the story just got old. This would have made a very good novel if she had kept the story going.

title: Gut wrenching and real horrors of refugees from Syria
content: I have seen various refugee stories on the news but none have ever touched me like this story. The trauma that this couple went through to try to stay alive. I decided to read because of the title as I have been infatuated with bees for a long time because of their decline. In this story they were very symbolic of their resilience. I highly recommend the Beekeeper of Aleppo. It was a learning experience for me.

title: Verified Purchase
content: This was a worthwhile read that takes you to a place you won't get to by watching news reports.  For me, the best books evoke thoughts/feelings/emotions and Beekeeper certainly accomplishes that, and it educates as well.  One facet of this book that is truly outstanding (but tragic) is the author's ability to compel the reader to feel the power and pain of loss, especially when that loss is through a senseless acts.
